docs.lead_paragraph: She lost Joey to asthma shortly before he was to turn 11 -- a searing memory for Earline Sierra, who recalls that as her son was having another of his many asthma attacks, ''he was talking to me, and he turned blue, and he stopped breathing.'' Now she fears for Jaime, 16, another son who has the disease.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Family Copes With a Disease It Well Knows Can Be Fatal

docs.abstract: Earline Sierra receives help with family expenses from Children's Aid Society, beneficiary agency of New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ALBANY — David Grandeau, the executive director of the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, has been reading fine print lately.

headline.main: Will Bush’s Health Plan Work? (7 Letters)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The President's Risky Health Plan'' (editorial, Jan. 26):
docs.abstract: Seven letters comment on Jan 26 editorial on Pres Bush's health care proposals; John Chalmers says plan falls far short of what is needed to address severity of problem; Saul J Stahl says shifting burden of selecting and paying for health benefits to employees would increase their cost sensitivity, allow better tailored coverage and allow small employers to provide additional important benefits; Lester Ostroy says more providers will be necessary to care for those currently uninsured; Christopher Taylor praises Bush plan, saying it will benefit those who have high deductibles and co-payments; Warren Greenberg, professor of health economics at George Washington University, says Bush plan could be first step in discarding antiquated employer-based system; Katherine Verleger praises reasoning of editorial; Adam E Block, doctoral candidate in health policy, says plan to tax insurance will not decrease number of uninsured; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''The President's Risky Health Plan'' (editorial, Jan. 26):

docs.lead_paragraph: Speaking of that Long Island Senate race, the Republican candidate, Maureen O'Connell, below, appears to be in good standing with the insurer WellCare.
docs.abstract: Maureen O'Connell, Republican candidate for Senate from Long Island, receives $5,000, corporate limit, from WellCare, health insurance company, and another $5,000 each from three of its divisions; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Speaking of that Long Island Senate race, the Republican candidate, Maureen O'Connell, below, appears to be in good standing with the insurer WellCare.
